<denchmark-link:https://github.com/nyj-ocean>@nyj-ocean</denchmark-link> if you check the code in train.py, you will notice mAP is calculated at 0.1 during training and at 0.001 on the last epoch. Thats why you see different results

<denchmark-link:https://github.com/nyj-ocean>@nyj-ocean</denchmark-link> best.pt currently saves at the lowest validation loss point, not the highest mAP point, so this could be the cause of the discrepancy. There is an ongoing debate about which to use actually, so perhaps this another point of evidence that we should switch back. The general argument in favor of saving at the lowest loss is that this should provide the best mAP across the different testing criteria, such as confidence levels, IOU thresholds, mAP@0.5 vs mAP@0.5:0.95 etc, whereas saving at the best mAP only applies to that specific metric.

<denchmark-link:https://github.com/nyj-ocean>@nyj-ocean</denchmark-link> also if you are running out of HDD space you can simply disable the backups here:
yolov3/train.py
Lines 364 to 367 in 53e3d55
# Save backup every 10 epochs (optional)
if epoch > 0 and epoch % 10 == 0:
